entry.title: [gbb-cct] Mitigate memory increase
Database::HasActiveTransactions() should be false when the DB is closed
entry.content:
asully flagged this while discussing error handling in FirstPartySetsDatabase (https://crrev.com/c/5314328/comment/58e6c6e5_08dc37d7/).
It appears that calling Database::Close() on an open db does not reset transaction_nesting_. Consequently, [HasActiveTransactions()](https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:sql/database.h;l=501-504;drc=133b2d903fa57cfda1317bc589b349cf4c284b7c) could return true after closing the database.

I checked in the code to add them last week, we just need to make the corresponding xml changes (so in terms of code changes this would practically be a no-op).

entry.content: This bug serves as a global tracking bug for all recipe changes that need to be made across different recipe repos to ensure that the task backend migration will run smoothly.

entry.title: Glitch At Typing on Keyboard When CPE Suggests Passwords
entry.content:
When there are CPE suggestions for passwords, CPE disappears every time when I realise the key in the keyboard and the KA bar is shifted down and up, which looks like a glitch.
It won't happen when there are no CPE suggestions.

entry.title: Element.scrollTo({ behavior: "smooth" }) stops working entirely after adding and removing a class
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. Go to https://codepen.io/depict_daniel/pen/eYXwdVY 2. Observe the contents in the red div smoothly scrolling around in an infinite loop 3. Press the "trigger chrome bug"-button 4. The button will add and remove a class, meaning that before and after the button press the DOM and CSS are exactly the same
Expected behavior: scrolling behavior is identical before and after button press
Actual behavior: The <div> is now no longer smoothly scrollable and the infinite loop scrolling back-and-forth in the div does no longer do anything
# Problem Description We're trying to build a feed-like UI to discover "looks". You can see in the following video where I'm demoing it first in firefox and then chrome:
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1yMmlRvKluby-i7pqvS2m3tZWlJQszwPB/view?usp=sharing
Note how in chrome, when scrolling down in the container of looks and then no longer hovering it, when it closes, the items are not scrolled to the top like how they are in firefox? (Happens in firefox at 0:06 and does not in chrome at 0:28/0:32) That's due to this bug.
We really want to be able to smoothly scroll a container programatically when it's set to `overflow: hidden` because the "look items" should only be scrollable when they are expanded. It works in firefox, safari but in chrome, setting `overflow: auto` once (which we need to do for the expanded state) breaks `scrollTo`, as one can see per the attached reproduction steps.
# Summary Element.scrollTo({ behavior: "smooth" }) stops working entirely after adding and removing a class
# Custom Questions #### Which component does this fall under? Blink>Scroll
#### Does this work in other browsers? Yes - This is just a Chrome problem
# Additional Data Category: API \ Chrome Channel: Canary \ Regression: No

entry.title: Improve description for Memory.Gpu.PrivateMemoryFootprint
entry.content:
I've seen a lot of questions and confusion about what `Memory.Gpu.PrivateMemoryFootprint` actually represents. The question if it's GPU texture memory or GPU process memory gets asked frequently. The description "A rough estimate of the private memory footprint of the gpu process" doesn't really clarify that.
My understanding is that the metric always(???) includes the GPU process CPU memory footprint as reported by the OS plus depending on the OS/architecture/platform/GPU it sometimes includes GPU memory as well. I believe lizeb@ has a better understanding of where it includes what.
Alternatively if we have this documented in a markdown file somewhere we could at least link to it from the histogram description.

entry.title: Refactor (GraphicsContext) stroke setup/representation
entry.content:
There are current three ways stroke shapes are painted (in roughly increasing order of complexity):
1) "Simple" solid strokes - used by some painters. 2) "Styled" strokes - used for "border-like" effects. 3) Fully specified StrokeData - used by SVG and <canvas>.
(1) could be represented by (2), and both (1) and (2) can be transformed into (3). (2) has some amount of "magic" associated with it to improve the rendering quality in certain cases (for "dashed" and "dotted"). This "magic" means that certain paint operations have side-effects on the GraphicsContext state.
This task aims to move the specification of strokes to a more explicit model, where the (few) places that need the side-effects instead explicitly resolve to the (3) representation and then use that for painting. GraphicsContext will have an interface for accepting a StrokeData, and also - for convenience - an interface for simple solid strokes. Future work may include moving the (2) type of stroke closer to the CSS painting code (since some "styles" are already handled on that level).

entry.title: Change the animation to enter/leave tab group
Reactive prefetch requests should be seen by extensions
DOM Clobbering mitigations - tracking bug
entry.content:
This is a tracking bug for implementation of DOM Clobbering mitigations.
The first step is to implement UseCounters to understand usage of DOM Clobbering within `window`, `document` and `form`.

entry.title: synchronous setCookie method throws no exception
entry.content:
The synchronous-setCookie method neither throws any exception nor returns anything if cookie failed to set.
We had a bug in our code but it was never discovered as the synchronous setCookie method was silent. After using the asynchronous-setCookie method and passing a ValueCallback, we found that cookie wasn't being set. The synchronous-setCookie method should either throw an exception or return a Boolean like the asynchronous-setCookie method.
CookieManager: https://developer.android.com/reference/android/webkit/CookieManager
synchronous setCookie: https://developer.android.com/reference/android/webkit/CookieManager#setCookie(java.lang.String,%20java.lang.String)
asynchronous setCookie: https://developer.android.com/reference/android/webkit/CookieManager#setCookie(java.lang.String,%20java.lang.String,%20android.webkit.ValueCallback%3Cjava.lang.Boolean%3E)

entry.title: Thinkpads (and other Windows devices) falling out of hardware encoding
entry.content:
There are reports about power consumption regressions when using Meet in Chrome on Windows in combination with VP9 as video codec. Tests have shown that the main reason is that Meet falls back from VP9 in hardware on devices that supports it (e.g. Lenovo Thinkpad L15 and T14) to instead run VP9 in software.
The goal of this task is to figure out the exact reason what triggers the fallback and fix it either in Meet/Chrome or in GPU drivers.

entry.title: "Reveal in source panel" button doesn't work before refreshing a page
entry.content:
Chrome Version : 124.0.6316.0 (Official Build) canary (arm64)
What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Open any site other than google.com, Open DevTools > Application > Frames > top 2. Navigate to google.com 3. Try clicking the "Reveal in sources panel" icon next to Document > URL
What is the expected result? Document opens in sources panel
What happens instead? Nothing happens. If you navigate to another tab in DevTools and then back to Applications, the button works and a network icon has appeared next to it.

entry.title: Move the caret by "paragraph" granularity should cross editing boundary
entry.content:
Chrome Version: 120.0.6099.126 OS: Platform independent, all platforms(macOS/Windows/Linux...) can reproduce this issue
What steps will reproduce the problem? (1) Open https://codepen.io/Peng-Zhou/pen/LYabZVR. (2) Ensure that p#two is rendered into two distinct lines. (3) Move the caret at the end of p#two, then click the button
What is the expected result? The caret moves to the end of p#one.
What happens instead? The behavior looks "line" granularity, the caret only moves to the previous line.

entry.title: Add specification link for resourceid and initiatorid
entry.content:
The attributes resourceID and initiatorID are currently not specified in the w3c resource timing specification. Once these attributes are properly specified, it would be beneficial to include a link in the codebase for improved readability. This update should be made in the third_party/blink/public/mojom/timing/resource_timing.mojom file.
Porject Explainer : https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ODMUQP9ua-0plxe0XhDds6aPCe_paZS6Cz1h1wdYiKU/edit?usp=sharing

entry.title: [Non-Regression][MultiMoniter]: Observed blank screen while connecting/disconnecting the multi-display
entry.content:
Chrome Version: M122 Beta #122.0.6261.21/15753.13.0 on Kled(Hatch) device LaCrOS Version : LaCrOS Dev RC #124.0.6315.2[LaCrOS-Only] OS: Chrome
Details: ----------------------------------------------------- 1)Accounts: Test account 2)Enterprise Enrolled: NO 3)Devices: Corp device Kled(Hatch) -X86/LaCros64 4)Repro on Ash-chrome: yes-M122 Beta #122.0.6261.21/15753.13.0 on Kled(Hatch) device 5)Mode: Normal mode 6)Frequency: Always
Enabled the lacros flags #lacros-stability = Dev #lacros-only = Enabled #enable-component-updater-test-request = Enabled
What steps will reproduce the problem? 1.Launch Lacros 2. Try to Connect the device to external moniter and Observe
What is the expected result? There should not be any screen blinking or glitches when connecting and disconnecting to multi monitor
What happens instead? Observed screen blinking when connecting and disconnecting to Multi-monitor
Note: 1) Issue is also seen in ash-chrome
This issue is also seen on M111 Stable #111.0.5563.152/15329.63.0 on Lava(Coral) device

entry.title: The tab is opened in new window with the window being half of the normal/usual size after dragging it out from full screen
entry.content:
Chrome Version: 123.0.6312.2 (Official Build) canary (arm64) ee77acc178bb8175e0f0b1967d1bd0bbcc9d5a82-refs/branch-heads/6312@{#6}
OS: Mac(11.4)
Feature Bug : https://issues.chromium.org/issues/326422875
Test Plan - https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ED_otHAVJCpb_-5VqeO67F1673aHRO6HUwvQwxZOBjw/ ￼
Precondition : launching Chrome with --enable-features="ImmersiveFullscreen" #enable-immersive-fullscreen-toolbar from chrome://flags
What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Launch Chrome and Open NTP 2. Open any website(ex: amazon.in or flipkart.com) in new tab 3. Enter full screen 4. Drag the tab out to open in new window 5. Observe the window size of the newly opened window
Actual Result : The tab is opened in new window with the window being half of the normal/usual size
Expected Result : The tab must be opened in new window with normal/usual size
Kindly refer the attached screencast
@bur : Could you please look into this.
Thanks!

entry.title: Eye dropper is not working in DevTools color picker, in wayland
entry.content:
We use the native 'Eye Dropper' API whenever it is available by detecting whether the feature is available (by `'EyeDropper' in window`).
However, in Linux Wayland, the feature is reported available and we try to use it even though the feature is not correctly working there (b/40800718).
As a solution: * The feature should not be reported available in Wayland until it is properly implemented.
As a workaround on DevTools side: * We're going to bring back the EyeDropper experiment for people to use a workaround to disable using native eye dropper.
It would have been better if we could understand whether the feature is working correctly on DevTools side and automatically disable it if it is not working; however, it seems like there is no way to do this on JS side.
See the user report: https://x.com/ChallengesCss/status/1760391573064347703?s=20
